video.title: 12 Beginner Python Projects - Coding Course
video.description:
Improve your Python skills by following along with 12 different Python project tutorials.

🎥 Course developed by Kylie Ying. Check out her YouTube channel: https://www.youtube.com/ycubed 

⭐️ Course Contents ⭐️
⌨️ (1:40) 1. Madlibs 
⌨️ (6:54) 2. Guess the Number (computer) 
⌨️ (13:17) 3. Guess the Number (user)
⌨️ (21:14) 4. Rock Paper Scissors
⌨️ (24:25) 5. Hangman
⌨️ (35:53) 6. Tic-Tac-Toe
⌨️ (59:59) 7. Tic-Tac-Toe AI
⌨️ (1:15:53) 8. Binary Search 
⌨️ (1:27:16) 9. Minesweeper 
⌨️ (1:51:55) 10. Sudoku Solver 
⌨️ (2:05:34) 11. Photo Manipulation in Python 
⌨️ (2:31:49) 12. Markov Chain Text Composer 

⭐️ Code ⭐️
💻 Madlibs / Rock Paper Scissors / Binary Search: https://github.com/kying18/beginner-projects
💻 Guess the Number: https://github.com/kying18/guess-the-number 
💻 Hangman: https://github.com/kying18/hangman 
💻 Tic-Tac-Toe + AI: https://github.com/kying18/tic-tac-toe 
💻 Minesweeper: https://github.com/kying18/minesweeper
💻 Sudoku: https://github.com/kying18/sudoku 
💻 Photo Editing in Python: https://github.com/kying18/pyphotoshop
💻 Markov Chain Composer: https://github.com/kying18/graph-composer

⭐️ More ways to connect with Kylie Ying ⭐️
Twitch KylieYing: https://www.twitch.tv/kylieying 
Twitter @kylieyying: https://twitter.com/kylieyying 
Instagram @kylieyying: https://www.instagram.com/kylieyying/ 
Website: https://www.kylieying.com

⭐️ Music Credits ⭐️
Alan Walker - Fade [NCS Release]: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=bM7SZ5SBzyY
Alan Walker - Force [NCS Release]: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=xshEZzpS4CQ

--

Learn to code for free and get a developer job: https://www.freecodecamp.org

Read hundreds of articles on programming: https://freecodecamp.org/news

topLevelComment.author: Ryan Hi
topLevelComment.text:
@32:27   The letters were registering but not added to the word guessed. Very frustrating.

# letters used
        # ' '.join(['a','b','cd']) ---> 'a b cd'
        print('You have used these letters: ', ' '.join(used_letters))

has to be used under these lines of code:

# what current word is (ie W - R D)
        word_list = [letter if letter in used_letters else '-' for letter in word]
        print('Current word: ', ' '.join(word_list))

so, it looks like this:

# what current word is (ie W - R D)
        word_list = [letter if letter in used_letters else '-' for letter in word]
        print('Current word: ', ' '.join(word_list))

        # letters used
        # ' '.join(['a','b','cd']) ---> 'a b cd'
        print('You have used these letters: ', ' '.join(used_letters))

replies.author: Dean G
replies.text:
@lmaooaooo Absolutely!
Programming isn't just writing code..it's about working out how to solve a problem.

It's about identifying what data you need to solve it, how are you going to store that data, what data structures are you going to use? What algorithms are you going to use to put data in and read it out from the structure. What algorithms are you going to use to process that data to achieve the end result.

You need to develop this yourself.
Oh, sure, you might need to be taught a few basic algorithms such as sorting, and data structures such as: arrays, lists, trees.

replies.author: Steven Craze
replies.text:
(player, opponent) are the arguments used within the function 'is_win'
(user, computer) are the variables defined within the function 'play' that are then fed as arguments to 'is_win'

'is_win' could have simply been defined with (x, y), but providing useful names as arguments helps with readability and understanding what the function is expecting as an input.

replies.author: Jovan Tan
replies.text:
@P K Hi again! After some thought (and trial and error), I think I somewhat understand how it works. Not entirely sure if it's what you're asking but let me try to explain it (with my very limited Python/programming knowledge). So maybe take it with half a pinch of salt :p also it's gonna be a pretty scuffed explanation so bear with me and let me know where I can try to explain further. I'll be using asterisks (*) to denote the starts and ends of a line.

So the line in question is *word_list = [letter if letter in used_letters else '-' for letter in word]*.

Firstly, a line like "x for x in variable" essentially summons each item within the variable. In this case, "letter for letter in word" summons, as you might guess, each letter of the word. To illustrate, if you were to replace the original line with *word_list = [letter for letter in word]*, the program would instead print out each letter in the word right from the get-go, instead of the "-" in the original code.

Now because we need to hide the letters at the start and also subsequently the un-guessed letters as the game progresses, instead of using "letter for letter in word", we want to print a dash (-) for each letter in the word instead. Thus there is a part in the code that says " '-'  for letter in word", which basically replaces each letter with a dash instead ('-' for letter in word). However, we need the correct letter to show up if it has been guessed correctly. This is where the whole line comes together.

!!!KEY PART!!!: To break the original line of code down, you may understand the line *word_list = [letter if letter in used_letters else '-' for letter in word]* as: 
if the letter that the user has input (used_letters) AND is part of the word (in word), summon the correct letter for the letter that has been input (letter... for letter in word). Otherwise, summon a dash for each letter (else '-' for letter in word).

Note that there are lines of code (as below) that add the letter that the user has just input into used_letters. So these lines kinda work together to make this line function as it does. The lines, just for your info, are:
*if user_letter in alphabet - used_letters:
            used_letters.add(user_letter)*

Finally, just note that this square bracket thing "[ ]" is used to create lists. So the line creates a list. 
I'm not too sure of the significance of this... maybe it affects how the word_list is printed? ... But the key parts should be above heheh.


Example: Word is "J A R".
Each time the user inputs a letter, say "J", that letter gets added to the set of used_letters. Since the word also happens to contain "J", "J" gets added into the list word_list. Meanwhile, "A" and "R" are in the word but not in the set of used_letters. 
So Python will print the list word_list with "J" for "J", "-" for "A", and also "-" for "R". 

Let me know if anything is confusing (as I suspect is the case)!


*If any experts see this and would care to correct me where I may have erred or missed out, please do! Or even to put forth a better explanation. Any input would be greatly appreciated :)

topLevelComment.author: Luis Garcia
topLevelComment.text:
There are at least 2 extra ways to concatenate strings. One is by adding a comma after the string. The advantage over + symbol for concatenation is that there is no need to convert a numeric variable to string type. In addition it adds an extra space. The other one that I recently discover is with %s. For example:
name = "Peter"
time = 2
print("Hi %s, nice to meet you again. I haven't seen you for %s years"%(name, time))

It is very similar to the format method. Nevertheless, I agree that the most convenient and easy to read is with f string

replies.text: Letter is just a place holder in the for loop for the word that you are guessing. You’re looping through a string, so letter equals every letter in word, one at a time. topLevelComment.author: Whatsthis
topLevelComment.text:
A note about the hangman not working for so many is when you copy the list of words and save it into words.py you will need to remove the {"data": at start and } at end so it's in list format.  e.g. words = ["aback","abaft","abandoned"]

Make sure you added the following to the top which is easily missed:
import string

Another issue is the list of words is all in lowercase, so with the default code anything inputted is transformed into uppercase so your letters will never match lower case list letters. Changes below:
set(string.ascii_lowercase)
user_letter = input('Guess a letter: ').lower() 

You can use this modification to make the used letter more apparent with what letters that have been used with this change below: 
print('You have used these letters: ', ' '.join(used_letters).upper())
also:
print('Current word: ', ' '.join(word_list).upper())

Also for those of you who can't start the script make sure you call the function to start hangman, the last line of code should be that function hangman()

topLevelComment.text:
May I please get someone's help on my code for hangman? 
Firstly, I get a single "-" for my current word, instead of showing multiple "-" for the length of the entire word.
Secondly, my program doesn't end even after I have correctly guessed all the letters of the word.

import random
from words import words
import string

computer_word = random.choices(words)
computer_letters = set(computer_word)


def hangman():
    alphabet = set(string.ascii_lowercase)
    used_letters = set()
    
    while len(computer_letters) > 0:
        print("You have used these letters: "," ".join(used_letters))
        
     
        print(computer_word)
        user_letter = input("Please guess a letter of alphabet: ").lower()

       
        print(computer_word)
        print(computer_letters)
        word_list = [letter if letter in used_letters else "-" for letter in computer_word]
        print("Current word: ", " ".join(word_list))
        if user_letter in alphabet - used_letters:
            used_letters.add(user_letter)
            
            if user_letter in computer_letters:
                #remove letter from computer_letters 
                computer_letters.remove(user_letter)

                

        elif user_letter in used_letters:
            print("You have used this letter before.")

        else:
            print("Please try again.")

    if len(computer_letters) == 0:
        print("You won!")

    


hangman()

topLevelComment.author: das sad
topLevelComment.text: 2:22:40 Theres a little mistake in code. You probably knew about it, but to simplify just carry on. You divide result by Kernel size squared to make average values, which is not true for border values, because there Kernel size is smaller and depends on how many Kernel elements were in calculation. Solution for this is to create another variable which determines how many calculations were actually made. But it will slow down the process. For small kernels it doesn't matter. For bigger could be significant.

replies.text:
def add(num1, num2): # creates the function
    return num1 + num2

add(5, 4) # calls the function

notice that I called the function using two integers, and not the variables num1 and num2, that's because num1 and num2 aren't actual variables, they're supposed to be replaced by the first number and the second number when the function is called. in this case, instead of player and opponent, it would be user (the player) and computer (the opponent)

topLevelComment.author: Mohammad Abdelrahman
topLevelComment.text:
Just a note, the code written at 6:06 is more important than all the projects combined. Modules and packages, and the __name__ variable. 

+ A small critique, the folder sample_madlibs should have the __init__.py file inside of it to be recognized as a package, yes python can work with packages without the __init__.py file, but it still should be included. because It specifies that the directory should be treated as a package. And these are the essential information required for whoever studies python. The code is important, but not as important as being able to handle manipulating files and organizing them, knowing how to call them and how to deal with them.

Experienced devlopers don't have a problem with these concepts because they work with it everyday, but someone who is learning programing on his on will face many problems because the majority of online teaching resources either skip such topics completely or give it a 1-2 minutes top explaining... before explaining a for loop.... as if for loops are so hard to grasp..

topLevelComment.author: ab cd
topLevelComment.text:
I tried to make computer solve the Sudoku in a different way, the  programme works but it is a bit slow(so I would like to make it find the solution faster).
The algorithm is more or less like this: 1) generate all the possible permutations of numbers between 1 and 9 (this assures that numbers are not repeated on each line), find all the possible solutions for each line,so the programme will delete all the permutations which are not the solution of each line.
For instance if the inital numbers of the first line are ["0","0","3","0","0","4","9,"0","0"] , the programme among all the possible permutations will exclude those where 3,4,9 are not in the right positions and will create a list with all the admissible solutions for each line following the same principle.

At the end it will be iterating each list of admissible solutions until the conditions that make sure that numbers in each column and square  are not repeated, are satisfied and if so the programme will interrupt.

replies.author: Nick Cortes
replies.text:
The rationale is usually learn the language you think you want to work in  first. So if web is your focus stick to JS, if you want to be more of a generalist (machine learning, data manipulation, scripting) you should probably start with python and then transition to JS later on.

Generally tho most of your skills are transferable it’s just about learning how each programming language does things differently (syntax and all the other little quirks)  

(also side note JS is a pain … I personally think Java is the best place to start) 

I’m only in my second year of CS… so grain of salt lol

replies.text:
I think I can help you, but I don´t know how to use GitHub yet (I'm kinda new) so sorry but I' m going to show you the code here :v  Well I hope it can help you:
-------------------------------------

import random
from typing import Counter

counter = 0  # I added this, if counter =0 we are gonna run guess() ////// if counter=1 we're gonna run computerGuess()
hola = True # Added this: basically "hola" is gonna be true forever, that's why at the end I'm going to put a while loop 


def guess(x):
    global counter #added, you have to type global so that way Python knows you're referring to the counter out of 'guess()'
    random_number = random.randint(1, x)
    guess = 0
    while guess != random_number:
        guess = int(input(f'Hi! please choose a number between 1 and {x}: '))
        if guess > random_number:
            print(f"Let's try it again, {guess} is too high")
        elif guess < random_number:
            print(f"Let's try it again, {guess} is too low")
    print(
        f"Fantastic! You just guessed the correct number, {random_number} is the correct answer!")
    counter = 1    #: Here is the end of guess() game , now counter is gonna be 1 to run computerGuess()


def computerGuess(x):
    global counter #added, you have to type global so that way Python knows you're referring to the counter out of 'guess()'
    low = 1
    high = x
    response = ''
    while response != 'c':
        guess = random.randint(low, high)
        response = input(
            f"Is {guess} the number? (C)\nIs your number lower? (L)\nIs your number higher? (H)").lower()
        if response == 'l':
            high = guess-1
        elif response == 'h':
            low = guess+1
    print(f"Excellent! I guess the number, {guess} is the answer!")
    counter = 0 #: Here is the end of computerGuess() game , now counter is gonna be 0 to run guess()


while hola:  #That way is gonna run forever, cuz hola is ever gonna be true
    if(counter == 0): 
        number = int(input('Elige: ')) # int, because input returns a string we want a number, so here you decide the high value
        guess(number)
    elif(counter == 1):
        number= int(input('Elige: '))
        computerGuess(number)

replies.author: Wendell Cook
replies.text: You don't actually have to import the json file. All you need to do is copy/paste the list of words into a python file and assign it the name "words" just as she does in the video. In your python editor create a new file in the same folder as the hangman.py file and name it words.py. Open the json file and select/copy everything within the brackets [ ] and including the brackets [ ]. i.e. ["aback","abaft", .... "zoo","zoom"]. Then in your newly created words.py file type "words = " without the quotations. Then paste the list of words you copied from the json file. Now when you "from words import words" in your hangman.py file you will be able to call words from the words.py file. Hope that makes sense.

topLevelComment.author: Zoran Stamenkovski
topLevelComment.text:
Can somebody helm me with my homework....I am beginner in Python...Thanks in advance


Create a global variable called myUniqueList. It should be an empty list to start.

Next, create a function that allows you to add things to that list. Anything that's passed to this function should get added to myUniqueList, unless its value already exists in myUniqueList. If the value doesn't exist already, it should be added and the function should return True. If the value does exist, it should not be added, and the function should return False;

Finally, add some code below your function that tests it out. It should add a few different elements, showcasing the different scenarios, and then finally it should print the value of myUniqueList to show that it worked.

replies.author: Eduard K
replies.text:
​@Brandon Hamilton  I am a self-learner as well. I think learning on your own has some benefits as well. You can choose what you want to learn and aren't bound to any curriculum. Just try to use python as a way to solve problems which you might have in the real world. Maybe you try to automate a mundane task and it doesn't matter how long it takes you to automate it still feels satisfying even if you could've just done the mundane task :D - I have only done this for some university work but maybe you could check out the book: https://www.pdfdrive.com/automate-the-boring-stuff-with-python-practical-programming-for-total-beginners-e196888154.html

i am currently studying something else so when it comes to career choices i am not sure myself about what i gonna do after that so no advice from me ;)because i dont know :D

here is a free book where i am at chapter 4 currently: https://runestone.academy/runestone/books/published/pythonds/index.html#

ROCK PAPPER SCISSORS with while loop for repetitive play if you loose,  i find it more easy to follow
import random

def play():
    options = ['rock', 'scissors', 'papper']
    won = 0
    tie = 0
    loose = 0
    while won != 1:
        #if tie == 1:
         #   print("tied")
        #if loose == 1:
         #   print("LOOOOSEEE!!!")
        user_choice = input(" Chose one of piatra , foarfece, hartie : ")
        computer_choice = random.choice(options)
        print (f"The computer has chosen : {computer_choice} sooo you...")

        if user_choice == computer_choice:
            print("tied")
            tie = 1
        if user_choice == "rock" and computer_choice == "papper":
            print("LOOOOSEEE!!!")
            loose = 1
        if user_choice == "rock" and computer_choice == "scissors":
            print("you are a champ!!!!")
            won =1
        if user_choice == "scissors" and computer_choice == "rock":
            print("LOOOOSEEE!!!")
            loose = 1
        if user_choice == "scissors" and computer_choice == "papper":
            print("you are a champ!!!!")
            won =1
        if user_choice == "papper" and computer_choice == "scissors":
            print("LOOOOSEEE!!!")
            loose = 1
        if user_choice == "papper" and computer_choice == "rock":
            print("you are a champ!!!!")
            won = 1
play()

replies.author: Kylie Ying
replies.text:
@Kate Moon first of all, affirmative action works against asian people. Second of all, if you are trying to say I got into MIT just because I’m female, I’ll let you know that is not the only redeeming quality that got me into this school. Yeah I have 2 X chromosomes, but I also set goals, work hard, and make things happen.

To everyone else reading this comment, to anyone else who has had this said to them because I know plenty have, know that anything you do in this world will come with criticism. People will try to invalidate your achievements and attribute them to the color of your skin, the gender you choose, the resources you may/may not have had access to, and so on. There are some things you were given and some things you can’t change. What’s important is that you took those things and you ran with them to get where you are now. And also know that your accomplishments are not defined by any of these things you have no control over.

Then the genius choose a square - any, it doesn't matter. Then I choose another vertex of the square. The G. is forced to choose the square in between my 2 squares to prevent me from winning. replies.author: Honyopenyoko
replies.text: This is so wrong it hurts...if your opponent is a 5-year-old, much less a genius, you’ll be forced to defend a non-vertex and end up in a tie or will have given the opponent multiple ways to win. It is absolutely proven that two players, each moving optimally, will tie every time. Yes, first move will win more often against an inexperienced opponent and vertices are strong opening moves but you will not win every time.

Do like me, just copy the code, practice and practice more and more and then everything will be clear after a while, dont pressure yourself to understand everything at your first try, do it once twince and thirst so your mind will be able to understand by itself what each step is revelant to. 
She is not coding while she make the video, it's a playback that goes X2 or maybe more and she just explain the concept wich is trully good for us! 

The idea here is not to learn syntaxes, it's not a course , it's for practicing, and by my experiences since my childrenhood, practicing the same exercices and do errors to correct them as mush as i need to understand the whole concep is the best way of learning. 

Sure it takes to mush time, but yes you are getting Up in syntaxes, logics and practice! 
So to whole beganers, just try to copy it correctly! 

Good luck every one and hope we will meet one day at Microsoft or google! <3
